author: barnabasbusa
content:
```yaml
participants:
# Super nodes
  - cl_type: prysm
    cl_image: ethpandaops/prysm-beacon-chain:peerDAS
    cl_max_mem: 8192
    cl_min_mem: 7000
    cl_max_cpu: 8000
    cl_min_cpu: 3500
    cl_extra_params:
      - --subscribe-all-subnets
      - --minimum-peers-per-subnet=1
  - cl_type: lighthouse
    cl_image: ethpandaops/lighthouse:unstable
    cl_max_mem: 8192
    cl_min_mem: 7000
    cl_max_cpu: 8000
    cl_min_cpu: 3500
    cl_extra_params:
      - --subscribe-all-data-column-subnets
  - cl_type: teku
    cl_image: ethpandaops/teku:nashatyrev-das
    cl_max_mem: 8192
    cl_min_mem: 7000
    cl_max_cpu: 8000
    cl_min_cpu: 3500
    cl_extra_params:
      - --p2p-subscribe-all-custody-subnets-enabled
  - cl_type: nimbus
    cl_image: ethpandaops/nimbus-eth2:pdsync
    cl_extra_params:
      - --subscribe-all-subnets=true
      - --sync-light-client=no
# Full nodes
  - cl_type: prysm
    cl_image: ethpandaops/prysm-beacon-chain:peerDAS
    cl_max_mem: 8192
    cl_min_mem: 7000
    cl_max_cpu: 8000
    cl_min_cpu: 3500
    cl_extra_params:
      - --minimum-peers-per-subnet=1
      - --data-columns-withhold-count=64
  - cl_type: lighthouse
    cl_image: ethpandaops/lighthouse:unstable
    cl_max_mem: 8192
    cl_min_mem: 7000
    cl_max_cpu: 8000
    cl_min_cpu: 3500
network_params:
  eip7594_fork_epoch: 0
  eip7594_fork_version: "0x50000038"
  genesis_delay: 300
snooper_enabled: true
global_log_level: debug
additional_services:
  - dora
  - goomy_blob
  - prometheus_grafana
dora_params:
  image: ethpandaops/dora:peerdas-as-deneb
ethereum_metrics_exporter_enabled: true
goomy_blob_params:
  goomy_blob_args: [
    combined,
    --sidecars 1,
    --throughput 1,
    --max-pending 3,
  ]
```

author: manunlp
content:
Sometimes it used to be working for 30 epochs and then it started to fork.

I think we need a way to really stress test the network. Prysm has the ` --data-columns-withhold-count` flag for that.
I also added a (not yet merged) flag that force ignoring incoming data columns from time to time, creating a fork on purpose.
The idea is to, very early, create forks and see how the network recovers (or not).

Currently, we are kind of waiting that a event creates a trouble on the network, creates a fork and then can't recover. This event can happen after 3 epochs, 12, 30 or 300.

If we could create fork on purpose, I think we would have a much higher degree of confidence, and debugging would be much faster as well.

author: manunlp
content: Because you don't have ENR for an inbound peer, Prysm does the contrary: First try to retrieve the csc from metadata. If not available, try from ENR. If not available, fallback to the default value.

author: manunlp
content:
Did prysm connect to nimbus or nimbus connected to prysm?
If prysm connected to nimbus (so prysm is an inbound peer for nimbus), then it's normal.

author: manunlp
content:
At slot 27 (producer `10-geth-prysm`), `02-geth-prysm` did not receive all the columns (and not enough columns to reconstruct the missing ones.)
==> It `02-geth-prysm` considers this block as unavailable.

Also, after it should rejoin the main fork, it does not.

So 2 Prysm issues in total.
